column1: Tolkien said that he had given every spare moment to the poems.<ref group="notes">This refers to the collection of sixteen poems titled ''[[The Adventures of Tom Bombadil]]''</ref>  He stated that he had lost all confidence in them, all judgement, and could not see them becoming a book unless [[Pauline Baynes]] was inspired by them (which he doubted).
The various items do not "collect", said Tolkien.  The only possible link was the fiction of coming from the [[The Shire
column2: Shire]] from the period of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', but it was an uneasy fit for some.  He had tried to make them fit better.  He had added a new ''Bombadil'' poem<ref group="notes">Number two in the series, "[[Bombadil Goes Boating]]"</ref> that would further "integrate" Tom into the period.
